lesson.title: Binary Classification Models
lesson.summary: Build logistic regression and decision tree models. Use stepwise to automate predictor variables selection. Score and compare models and interpret the results.

atoms.title: Intro
atoms.text:
Introduction to Logistic Regression

Logistic regression is one of the most basic forms of regression modeling. It’s part of a family of “generalized linear models” or GLM for short. This basically means that the formula is very similar to that of a linear regression. However since the target variable is binary, instead of a continuous numeric variable, the target variable has to be modified to fit this GLM formula. See the video below for more on the structure of Logistic Regression.

atoms.title: Logistic Regression
atoms.instructor_notes:
Please refer to Patrick's course [Problem Solving with Advanced Analytics](https://classroom.udacity.com/courses/ud976) if you're not familiar with his course.

*Ln* or "Natural Log" is the logarithm with base e. You can review the natural logarithm [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_logarithm)

atoms.title: Logistic Regression - Continued
atoms.instructor_notes:
If you're unfamiliar with Alteryx, feel free to [download the 14-day free trial](http://www.alteryx.com/download) here to learn more about this software program.

There are free alternatives to running logistic regression and you can check out these two software options:

[Weka](http://www.cs.waikato.ac.nz/ml/weka/)

[R](https://www.r-project.org/about.html)

atoms.title: Exercise
atoms.text:
Now it's your turn to build a logistic regression model. Follow the following steps to build the model. Then answer the questions below.

Steps to Build the Model

* Use an *Input* tool to bring in the HotelLoyaltyData.csv file found at the bottom of the page. * Use a *Select* tool to set the each variable to the correct data type. * Use the *Create Samples* tool to create Samples of dataset and set 70% for the estimation sample and 30% for the validation sample. * Use the *Logistic Regression* tool and set the target variable as **Redeemer** * Select all variables as predictor variables. * Deselect **Customer Key**, **First Name**, **Last Name**, and **Redeemer** as predictor variables. * Deselect any **categorical, non-numeric** variables that contain more than four categories (Hint: use the field summary tool to figure out which ones to remove)

question.prompt: What is the r-squared of the model?
How many predictor variables are statistically significant (not including the intercept)?

atoms.title: Logistic Regression - Stepwise
atoms.instructor_notes:
#### Selecting Variables for the Stepwise tool
Ben forgot to show that we needed to go back into the Logistic Regression Tool and select all of the possible variables in order to use the Stepwise Regression Tool. The Stepwise Regression tool needs to figure out all of the possible variables it can calculate first and it takes this list of possible variables from the Logistic Regression Tool output.

As you follow along, please remember to go back into the Logistic Regression Tool and select back all of the possible variables before you run the Stepwise Regression Tool.

#### Region
The `region` variable should be a categorical variable, meaning that the numbers you see in the Hotel Loyality file should be formatted as a string and not a number. Otherwise, you will not get the same results that Ben got from the Stepwise Regression Tool

#### AIC vs BIC
This information is from the [Stepwise Regression Tool description on Alteryx's website](https://help.alteryx.com/2018.3/Stepwise.htm): "A choice of two different adjusted fit measures are provided to the user, the Akaike information criterion (or AIC) and the Bayesian information criterion (or BIC). These two measures are similar to one another, but the BIC places a larger penalty on the number of variables included in the model, typically resulting in a final model with fewer variables than is the case when the AIC is used."

atoms.title: Steps
atoms.text:
To start, let's build out the model. You'll be adding a stepwise tool to the same model you build in the previous quiz. If you don't have the model already built. Here are the steps.

Steps to Build the Model

* Use an *Input* tool to bring in the 'HotelLoyaltyData.csv' file found at the bottom of the page. * Use a *Select* tool to set the each variable to the correct data type. * Use the *Create Samples* tool to create samples of dataset and set 70% for the estimation sample and 30% for the validation sample. * Use the *Logistic Regression* tool and set the target variable as **Redeemer** * Select all variables besides **Customer Key**, **First Name**, **Last Name**, and **Redeemer** as predictor variables. * Add a *Stepwise* tool

question.prompt: What is the R-Squared Value of the model?
Which fields were removed from the prediction model as a result of the Stepwise tool?

atoms.title: Logistic Regression - Stepwise Quiz
atoms.instructor_notes: **Clarification:** In the video, it states that a variable called *IncomeU* is dropped from the model. *IncomeU* is one of the dummy variables created by using the categorical variable *income*. When the *income* variable is dropped from the model, so are all the dummy variables associated with it. For a refresher on dummy variables, see [here](http://dss.princeton.edu/online_help/analysis/dummy_variables.htm).

atoms.title: summary
atoms.text:
#### Key Summary

Note that the Stepwise Regression tool is a tool to help you **reduce** and figure out which predictor variables have a good chance of being in the model, but it is not a tool that can automatically find all of the appropriate predictor variables in one run. 

There is still a lot of work that needs to get done to explore the predictor variables that the Stepwise Regression tool gives you. The Stepwise Regression tool will speed up the process for you in choosing predictor variables.

atoms.title: Download
atoms.text:
Installing the Model Comparison Tool

1. Go to https://gallery.alteryx.com and sign in to your account. If you do not have a Sign In create one via the Sign Up section 2. Once signed in go to the District portion of the Alteryx Gallery and click on Predictive District 3. Once inside of the Predictive District go to the Model Comparison tool 4. Download the file and open it up 5. When you open it up Alteryx will open as well asking you to import a workflow package; agree to this and say Import. This will download the information you need. 6. Once the workflow/macro opens, Run the workflow and hit Save. 7. Go to Options -> User Settings -> Edit User Settings -> Macros, add an entry there (click the **+** button) 8. Click the **...** button next to search path and select the Model Comparison file you downloaded. Click **Apply**. 9. Close Alteryx and open a new instance of Alteryx. In the Predictive Section you should see the new Model Comparison tool.

atoms.title: rocr error
atoms.text:
#### ROCR error

When running the Model Comparison Tool, if you get stuck with an error that says `Error in install.packages("ROCR", repos = repo)`, there is a permission error in your computer that is preventing Alteryx from installing an R package. This means that Alteryx needs to download additional files in the R system to run this Model Comparison tool in Alteryx, but cannot do it.

atoms.title: help
atoms.text: Follow the steps below to download the package manually. If you have trouble following these steps, feel free to reach out on [Knowledge](https://knowledge.udacity.com) for assistance or your IT staff (if you're at work).

atoms.title: step 1
atoms.text:
#### Step 1 

In Windows Explorer, navigate to your Alteryx folder and find the `R.exe` file in your R folder.

atoms.title: step 2
atoms.text:
#### Step 2

Double-click on `R.exe` and type in the command `install.packages("ROCR")`.

Choose a server location that is closest to you and click on Ok.

atoms.title: step 3
atoms.text:
#### Step 3

Wait a couple of seconds and the package will download. You will see the success message:

**package 'ROCR' successfully unpacked and MD5 sums checked**

Close out of the `R.exe` application and rerun your Alteryx workflow.

atoms.title: Decision Tree Model
atoms.instructor_notes: M&M's are chocolate candy if you're not familiar with the brand.

atoms.text:
## Additional Reading

[Information about the Decision Tree tool in Alteryx](http://help.alteryx.com/10.1/index.htm#cshid=rpart.htm)

[10-minute reading about Decisions Trees](https://webdocs.cs.ualberta.ca/~aixplore/learning/DecisionTrees/InterArticle/6-DecisionTree.html)

atoms.title: Notes
atoms.text:
#### Important Concepts to Review

**Root Node Error**: A percentage of how many of the data points went to the incorrect terminal node (predicted incorrectly) when all of the data points are validated against themselves within the entire training set (the Estimation dataset).

**Pruning Table**: Lists out the levels in the decision tree with their related error terms with cross-validation samples.

atoms.title: notes 2
atoms.text:
#### Important Concepts to Review

**Confusion Matrix**: A matrix (or table) that lists out all of the possible prediction results when we validate our model against our validation set. This confusion matrix is one of the best methods to review the accuracy and precision of your model as well as to understand any model bias in classifying your data points.
**If you are using Alteryx 11 please select this option below on your Decision Tree tool to see the report from the video**

atoms.title: Steps
atoms.text:
Prepare for the Quiz

Before beginning the quiz, build out the same decision tree model that you just observed. * First, use an Input Data tool to bring in the **Hotel Loyalty Data** file * Second, use a Select tool to set the data types of each variable * Third, use a Create Samples tool and select 70% as the estimation percentage * Fourth, attach a Decision Tree tool and select the variables to be used in the model * Fifth, attach *Browse* tools to both the R and I output nodes Use the results found in the browse tools to answer the following questions.

question.prompt: What are the 2 most important variables to the model?
When classifying all Yes's against the Cross Validation sample, what is the overall accuracy?

atoms.title: Q1
atoms.text:
### Variable Importance Plot

To answer the first question of which two variables are most important to the model, you can use the variable importance plot.

atoms.title: Q1 Note
atoms.text: You can clearly see at the top that the bars that indicate the importance of the variable are longest for `Spend` and `Stays.Per.Year`.

atoms.title: Q2
atoms.text:
### Confusion Matrix

To see the accuracy of the yeses in the model, you can use the confusion matrix.

atoms.title: Q2 Note
atoms.text:
You can see the percentages along the right side of the graph. In this case, 168 of the 248 (68%) of the yeses were classified correctly.

If you are getting 87% then you need to adjust your complexity parameter from 0 to Auto.

atoms.title: Video Transcript
atoms.text:
You just learned the fundamentals of what a decision tree is and you also saw how to build and validate your own model using Alteryx. Next, we'll compare our models against each other in order to pick the best one for production.

You may be asking yourself, why are we comparing models against each other if we already validated both models?

Well I like to think it's just good practice to view models side by side. And as you are going to see there are a couple of ways to do this using the Model Comparison tool. What we are going to do look for is the overall accuracy of each of the models as well as the lift/gains chart.

This lift chart is based on aggregating data into 10 groups. These groups are ordered based on the predicted probability of a favorable response for each model. The response is then compared to what would be expected if the selection of prospects was done randomly.

Let’s look at these over in Alteryx.

atoms.title: Link
atoms.text:
Model Comparison

To learn more about the Model Comparison tool, follow this [link](http://help.alteryx.com/current/index.htm#Model_Comparison.htm) To learn more about the Gain and Lift charts, follow this [link](http://www2.cs.uregina.ca/~dbd/cs831/notes/lift_chart/lift_chart.html) To learn more about the Precision vs Recall chart, follow this [link](https://www.quora.com/What-is-Precision-Recall-PR-curve) To learn more about the ROC chart, follow this [link](http://www.dataschool.io/roc-curves-and-auc-explained/) If you are getting a lot of **errors** setting up the model comparison tool please review posts on https://knowledge.udacity.com

atoms.title: Video Transcript
atoms.text:
We have our model chosen so the only thing we have to do is to predict who is going redeem a future marketing campaign. When we put a model into production it is referred to as scoring the model. Which simply means taking each individual record and applying the model to them which gives their probability to redeem the offer.

I’m going to have you take a stab at this first with our completed model and one individual to predict. Then we will take the full dataset and score it in Alteryx.

atoms.title: categorical significance
atoms.text:
After we run this Logistic Model we can see that the categorical variable Status has some classes that are not statistically significant. There a couple of things to keep in mind when something like this occurs and why in this case I kept Status in my model.

1. It is not possible to keep only part of a categorical variable
2. If NO class in a categorical variable is significant, then you may consider not using the variable at all.
3. If ANY class in a categorical variable is significant, then you should keep it.
4. A combination of classes in a categorical variable is possible with testing, but it should make logical sense though.
   * In this case Status.Gold is significant but Status.Silver & Status.Platinum are not. To create a Gold vs. Other does not make logical sense since Gold is between Silver and Platinum.

atoms.title: exercise
atoms.text:
Now that we have results, we can use them to make predictions! In order to better understand how the results lead to predictions, let's first do it manually. In the next section, we'll explore how to do it using Alteryx.

Steps

* Start with the logistic regression equation.
* In order to actually predict the probability of a positive response (P), we need to transform the model. Using algebra, the equation can be changed to look like this:

* Substitute the coefficients in for the betas (or alphas).
* Substitute the values for the individual in for the Xs.
* Calculate the value of P, or the probability that a person will redeem.

You can find two Microsoft Excel files in the supporting materials at the bottom of the page. 
* The **'Logistic Validation'** file has the coefficients from the model along with the values for the individual you'll be making a prediction for. Use this to make your calculations to answer the quiz question.
* The **'Logistic Validation Answer'** file has the calculations used to find the answer. Don't peak before you give it a try on your own!

**Note:** We're doing this by hand in Excel first to give you a good sense of how things work when scoring a data set. In the next section, you'll learn how to score your data set in Alteryx.

question.prompt: What is the likelihood that the individual will redeem?

atoms.title: Share
atoms.text:
#### Scoring the Model
Now that we have scored the model, it is time to report our findings to our boss. Here's what your boss has requested. 
* Create a dataset that contains only the individuals who have a greater than 50% probability of redeeming an offer. 
* Only include the Customer Key, First and Last Names, and the likelihood they will redeem an offer. 
* Sort the data with the highest likelihood individuals are at the top.

At the bottom of the page you can see the example output. Don't peek until you've tried it yourself!

#### Flowchart

Make sure you setup your flowchart exactly what Ben did or else you will not get the same results. Below you will find Ben's flowchart for your reference.

question.prompt: How many individuals are at least 50% likely to redeem the offer?

atoms.text: # Learning Summary The purpose of this learning summary is to provide the high level steps to build and use Logistic regression models to make a business decision. Along the side are suggested Alteryx tools to use while implementing the model.
